q.p: I thinke it meete as long as I am in this tabernacle, to stirre you vp by putting you in remembrance.

div.head: A Remedie for Securitie.

q.p: Let your Laughter be turned into mourning, and your Ioy into heauines.

div.p:
The occasion of choosing this Text. IT was a good piece of pollicie which the King of Aram commanded his two and thirtie captaines when they were to goe out to battell against Israel: Fight (saide he) neither with small nor great, saue onely against the King of L. King. 22.31. Israel. He knew, that the King beeing once slaine, the whole armie would the sooner be discomfited. The like pollicie, I thought very fitting for me to obserue at this time. Many and great are the sinnes of this generation, and (as it was said of Sodom) the crie of them is come vp before the Gen. 18.21. Lord: But there is one grand-sinne, vpon which all the rest haue their dependance, which, if we whose office it is to fight the good fight of 1. Tim. 6.12. faith, might be so happie as to subdue, doubtlesse we should see Sathan fall downe from heauen like lightning Luk. 10.18., and many come to amendment of life out of his snare, which are (now) taken of him at his will 2. Tim. 2.26.. And this is the sinne of Securitie. Against this I haue thought good to bend my whole force at this time, and for that ende, I haue out of this brooke of S. Iames his Epistle, chosen this clause, as a smooth stone, by which I may (if the Lord shall please so to blesse my leuelling) smite this Goliath in the forehead, and make it to fall groneling to the earth 1. Sam. 17.40.49. which euery where, and in euery
place doth (like that monster of the Philistims) so intolerably blaspheme the liuing God. This is my generall drift, and this is also (as I may so call it) the Shaft, which I haue chosen out of the Lords quiuer for this purpose.

The ••••• sion of 〈…〉 .The words may be deuided into two parts: The first is, a Restraint from something which is euill; Laughter and Ioy. The second is, a perswasion to a Good contrarie thereunto, Mourning and Heauines. Of both these in course.

In handling the first part,The 1. Part. it must first be enquired what Laughter it is, and what Ioy, against which S. Iames setteth himselfe in this place.What Laught • r & Ioy S. Ia • es 〈◊〉
••• eth. Laughter, is one of those endowments with which God furnished the Nature of man at his first creation, and therefore cannot be simply euill. Againe it is saide, that Abraham Ge • 17.17. laughed when God promised him a sonne, which generally is interpreted to be that Reioycing of his in the Day of Christ, which our Sauiour himselfe reporteth of himI • h. 8.56. for which cause Izhak had his name giuen him by Gods appointmentGen. 17.19. as a memoriall thereof, it beeing as much to say in English as Laughter. When the Lord brought againe the captiuitie of Zion (said the thankefull people after the returne frō Babylon) then was our mouth filled with Laughter Psal. 126.1.2.. The same may be also saide of Ioy. For among the Fruits of the Spirit, Ioy is numbredGal. 5.22., and it is a blessing promised, that the voice of Ioy shall be in the Tabernacles of the Righteous Psal. 118.15.. Therefore to auoide all ambiguitie of tearmes, and to know precisely and distinctly, what it is which S. Iames here disswades, we must thus distinguish. There is a twofold Ioy, A tw • f • ld Ioy. A Holy Ioy. or Laughter mentioned in Scripture: The one a Holy Ioy; The other a Hellish Ioy. The Holy ioy hath for the author of it, the Spirit of God; therefore it is called Ioy in the holy Ghost Ro • . 14.17.: the matter of it, is the light of Gods countenance Psal. 4.6.7. the assurance of his grace in Christ, the feeling ones selfe to be clothed with the garments of saluation Isa. 61.10. the measure of it such that it
is vnspeakable 1. P • t. 18.; the perpetuitie such, that no man can take it from those that haue inIoh. 16.22.: None can conceiue it but he which feeleth it, the stranger shall not meddle with it, saith SalomonProu. 14.10.. The fruits of it, are, Ioy in the word Ier. 15.16.; Ioy in the house of God Psal. 122 1.; Ioy in the liberty and free Preaching of the Gospel Phil. 1.18.; Delight in the companie of Gods Saints Psal 16.3., Ioy in Afflictions Rom. 5.3. Ioy in the Conuersion of othersAct. 11.18.: Base account of the worldPhil. 3.8.. This is a Holy Ioy; neither is it the purpose of the Apostle to restraine this Ioy, but to enforce it rather: for indeede the Mourning which he perswades, makes way for this Ioy. Now the other Ioy is a Hellish Ioy, A Hellish Ioy. the other Laughter is deuillish. Salomon calleth them all Fooles whose hearts are enueigled with itEccle. 7.6.. Peter tearmeth them bruit beasts lead with sensualitie 2. Pet 2.12.. This Ioy is either in wicked things, or els in things (in their owne nature tolerable) after a wicked manner. First, it is in wicked things. It is a pastime to fooles to do wickedly Prou. 14.23.. It is a Ioy to drunkards to be at it earely, and to sit till they be inflamed Is • . 5 11. The Twilight is welcome to the Adulterer Iob. 24.15.. The griping Nimrods of the world, reioyce in their taking men vpon aduantages, they dance vpon the thresholds of those which are fallen into their hands proudlyZeph. 1.9., & they spoile the poor when they haue drawne him to their net Psal. 10.9.. Ahab is soone out of his sullen humor, when news is come that Naboth is dead1. King. 21.16.. The enuious and malitious person is mooued to Ioy at the destruction of him whom he hates Iob 31.29.. The profane ones make themselues merry with the disgrace of those which runne not with them to the same excesse. Ishmael giereth at Isaac Gen 21.9., and the Philistims must haue Samson in to make them pastime I • d. 16.25.. Holy Iob was as a tabret to the godlesse onesIob. 17.6., and the Drunkards made songs vpon Dauid
• sal. 69.12.. Thus this ioy is in euill things. Or els (secondly) it is in allowable things after an vngodly manner. Honour, Wealth, Prosperitie, Beautie, a Table richly deckt, an ouerflowing cup, a faire house, &c. these things in themselues are not Euill, yet there is a Ioy in these of
which I may say as Paul did of the Corinthians Reioycing, that it it is not good 1. Cor. 5.6.: As, namely when men trust in them, and boast of them Psal. 49.6., and set their hearts thereon Psal. 62.10.. Thus that vain-glorious Haman, hauing crept into some grace at Court, when he comes home, must needes send and call for his friends, to tell of the glorie of his Riches, and of all the things wherein the King had promoted him Est. 5 10.11.. Thus Nebuchadnezzar walketh in his Royall palace, and looking about him, saith, Is not this great Babel which I haue Dan. 4 27. built? Thus the proud women in the Prophets time, walked with stretched out necks Isa. 3.16., priding themselues in their beautie. Thus the Epicures and belly-gods in Amos his daies, ate the lambes of the flocke, and calues out of the stall, and dranke wine in bowles Amo. 6.4.6.. Thus the Merchants of Tyre, which was the Marte of the people for many Yles Ezeck. 27 3., did lift vp their hearts because of their Riches Ezeck. 28.5.. Here is Ioy in things not Euill, but yet after a manner which is not good. Now the fruits and effects of this Ioy are thus registred in Scripture: Deepe securitie; They knew nothing (saith Christ, of the reioycing people in the daies of Noe) till the flood came Matth. 24.39.: Secret soothing and flattering of the HeartDeut. 29.19.: Confident expectation of nothing but Quietnes (I shall neuer be mooued Psal. 10.6.:) Carelesnes to inquire after matters of religiō, (The wicked is so proud that he seeketh not Ver. 4.: Putting farre off the euill day Am. 6.3., The vision is for many daies to come Ezec. 12.27.. Intolerable Pride ioyned with contempt of others, (Pride is as a chaine vnto them Psal. 73.6.: No respect to the necessities of Gods children, (No man is sorie for the affliction of Ioseph Am. 6.6.:) A mocking of Gods Messengers 2. Chr. 36.16.: A desperate resolution to take pleasure while it is to be had, and not to feare the day of vengeance, (Let vs eate and drinke, to morrow we shall die 1. Cor. 15.32..) Thus haue I laboured to let you see out of the Scripture, what Laughter and what Ioy it is which Iames intendeth here. In a word, thus: It is a fleshly Ioy, delighting in things simply Euill, or els in the good blessings of God, after a grosse and sensuall sort, by
which the heart is so setted vp, and so lulled • sleepe, that it makes men runne on in a kind of secure course, without any awe of Gods maiestie, or constant care to auoide the wrath which is to come. This is the short of it: and, the Necessitie of seeking to suppresse this Ioy, is the Doctrine commended vnto vs in this place.
Reasons to shew the equitie of this Doctrine,The substance of the doctrine of the 1. part. & the Reasons to confirme it. and by which to enforce it vpon euery of our soules, may be these.

Reason. 1 1. It is directly contrarie to that which the spirit of God perswades all Christians vnto. It is their dutie to hate euill Psal. 97.10., therefore not to delight in it: to weepe for it (as we shall see anon) therefore not to laugh at the committing it. They are commanded to set their affections vpon the things aboue Col. 3.2., and therfore not to ensnare their hearts with these baser ioyes: They are taught to seeke after Durable riches Prou. 8.18., therefore not to dote vpon fading wealth: after a house not made with hands, but eternall in the heauens 2. Cor. 5.1. Heb. 13.14., and therefore not to be bewitched with the conueniencie of earthly dwellings: after Sitting at table in the kingdome of God Luk. 13.2 • ., and therefore not to reioyce in earthly belly-cheare: after the Honour which shall be to the saints Psal. 149 9., and therefore not to be puffed vp with worldly pompe: to long for the Congregation of the first borne, and the spirits of iust and p • rfit men Heb. 12.23., and therefore not to place contentment in carnall fellowship. This is then one reason: This Ioy is directly contrarie to the maine streame of Christianitie. It is a reason of Pauls in some things. This becommeth Saints Ephe. 5.3., This becommeth the Gospel Phil. 1.27., therefore it must be: The reason is the same in this: This becommeth not Saints: This becommeth not the Gospel, therefore it must not be.

Reason. 2 2. This kind of reioycing, is neuer without the mixture of some secret bitternes. Euen in Laughter the heart is sorrowfull Prou. 14.13.. And there is a double reason for it. 1. Carnall men seldome haue their desire in euery particular, and the want of that which is desired breeds a vexation
greater by degrees then the contentment in the things enioyed. Take Haman for an example: He went from court with a glad heart, and at home vanted of his honour, yet (saith he) All this doth not auaile me, as long as I see Mordecai the Iewe sitting in the Kings gater.
〈…〉 . 1 • . He was so haunted with a spirit of Emulation against Mordecai, that it did distast all that sweetnes which he conceiued in his honour. And still, it is (ordinarily) so in the prouidence of God, that worldly men haue in their prosperities something or other comes athwart them, which galleth them as much, as the accomplishment of their desires in other things may seeme to content them. 2. Inward terrours (as furies) do alwaies follow those, who doe willingly cherish in their bosomes, and practise in their liues any knowne corruption. A sound of feare is in their eares Iob. 15.21., and it is their iudgement to haue trembling heartsDeut. 28.6 • .. Well may they set a face vpon the matter, and feast and drinke away their cares, yet they can haue no true inward quiet. For there is no peace to the wicked, saith God Isa. 57.21.. So then this is the second reason: It is no solide, but a meerely superficiall Ioy, and therefore it is an idle thing to entertaine it.

Reason. 3 3. It is a reioycing of no continuance. The reioycing of the wicked is short, and the ioy of Hypocrites is but a moment Iob. 20.5.. Salomon likeneth it to a fire of Thornes vnder a pot Eccle. 7.8., which crackleth and blazeth awhile, but suddenly dieth. This kind of Ioy is truly called short in two respects. 1. Because the things themselues reioyced in, are so subiect to hazard. Honour a blast: Beautie a perishing flower: Wealth hath wings like an egle Prou. 23 5., and is sudenly gone:Non amo illam fortunam rudentibus aptam. Tusc. Qu. and as the heathen said of the wealth of Marchants that it hangeth vpon Ropes, so it may be said of all the contentments of the world, they doe not hang vpon a three-fold cord, which (as the saying is) cannot be easily broken Eccle. 4.12., but vpon a single twine, which is snapt in sunder with a twitch: And they which looke highest and beare the greatest port, amp; most study the perpetuating of
their fortunes, are but in the state of Counters, which now stand for pounds, and forthwith go but for a farthing. 2. Because life it selfe, in which all these things are enioyed, is but short; Our d • ies are more swift then a post, they passe with the most swift ships, and as the Egle which flieth to the pray Iob. • 25 26.: Now carnall men in their reioycing haue but an estate for tearme of life at the vtmost: For, when a wicked man dieth his hope perisheth P • o • . 11.7., and what hope hath an hypocrite if God take away his soule: I • b 27 8. so then, if this Laughter be but momentanie, if this ioy be but for a season Heb 11.2 • . P • p ac • t & vide • , sed ••• d vid •• que placetq • e non • amen in uen • — Oui •• d • Narc •• so.; surely the counsell of Iames aduising vs to reiect it, is not vaine: For what wise man will set his heart vpon that, which (like a shadowe in the water) he may see and affect and catch after, but can neuer lay hold on.

Reason. 4 4. The conclusion of this Ioy is fearefull. The end of it is heauinesProu. 14.13., and Woe be to you which now laugh, for you shall waile and weepe Luk. 6.25.. If you aske what Heauines: Heare what Abraham said to the rich man in hell: Thou in thy life time receiuedst thy pleasures, now therefore thou art tormented Luk. 16.25.. Thus in the end, it bites like a serpent Prou. 23 3 • ., and leades downe to the chambers of death Prou. 7 27.: Here is Ioabs Kisse attended vpon with a secret stab2. Sam. 20.10., & wheras the pleasures of sinne were but for a season Heb. 11.25., the woe which followeth will be perpetuall. The worme dieth not, the fire neuer goeth out Ma • k. 9.44.: The breath of the Lord, like a riuer of brimstone doth kindle it n=t" Isa. 30.33.. This is the last reason but not of the least validitie. The wise mans Eies are in his head saith Salomon Eccle. 2.14.. He looketh not onely vpon the present face of things, but considereth before what the issue will be. It is no good purchase, to procure an endles woe, for a little sliding shadow of contentment. Thus I haue laboured to fortifie S. Iames his counsell with foure effectuall reasons, that so we may haue no colour of reason to reiect it. This carnal • ioy, if it be againtst the generall drift of Christianitie, if it haue not that fulnes
of conte • tment which it promiseth, if it be of no continuance, if it will certainely set in such a cloud, out of which will arise an eternall tempest neuer to be blowne ouer with any tract of time, how must not the counsell giuen be worthie to be accounted of, which aduiseth vs to tur • e our Laughter into another tune, and our secure I • y, into some sadder qualitie. I haue expounded and prooued the doctrine, now let me make vse.

This doctrine well agreeth with the Times.The Vs • . Nineueh was called a Reioycing City L ••• 2.15., this may truely be tearmed a Reioycing age; and like the people of Laish, we dwell carelesse, quiet, and sureI ••• . 1 •
• . in our owne opinion. Euery man sings a Requiem to his owne heart. God hath of his goodnesse blessed vs with peace, and peace (through our corruption) hath brought forth intolerable securitie. Religion is become nothing but a matter of Title, we haue a name (as was said of SardiR •• . •• .1.,) but all is little other then a very vizard of godlinesse. Are we not all generally without any feare of euill? Doth not euery man applaud himselfe in his course, and make himselfe beleeue that his fashion and carriage is as it ought to be? Doth not euerie companie, carry the very face of carnall quietnesse, men vpholding and beating vp one another (like the stones in an Arch) in their carelesnesse? Examine our thoughts, consider our speeches, see into our houses, looke abroad vpon the current of the Times, and see whether pleasure and Epicurisme, and that mad mirth (which Salomon speakes of
• ccle. 2.2.) haue not engrossed the greatest part. I would it had but a weeke (which yet is a very vnreasonable disproportion) for one serious minute about matters of godlinesse. This is made to be the very Ende of all: And as it was a Lawe in Ahashuerosh his court (beeing giuen to pleasure and iollitie,) that no man might enter it, being cloathed with sackcloth Est. 4.2., which is a mourners weede, so, nowe a dayes men cannot abide that which may minde them any way to intermit
their carelesnesse: A discourse o • conference of religion dasheth all, and seemeth alwaies as vnseasonable, as is the snowe in summer Prou. 26.1.. A sermon of repentance is the very Burden of the Lord: either we be like Faelix Act. 24.26., not at leisure to heare it, or we make iests with our mouths Bu • e 33 •• ., and as old Lot to his profane sonnes in Law, so we seeme to many as though we did mocke Gen. 19.14.: say we what we will, you will say to your selues, we shal • haue peace De •• . 2 • .19., the Euill shall not come Am • . •• .. Thus we stop the Eare like the Adder Psal 58 4., and although the Lord • ing many alarmes to awake vs f • om the bed of securitie, yet we resolue (like the strumpet in Salomon) to take our sillPro 17.18., and determine (as those in Ieremies time) to do • whatsoeuer thing goe • h out of our owne mouth Ier. 4.15.. This is the sickenesse of the times, a disease which hath spread it selfe in • o euery place. I say as Christ did to the accu • ers of the Adulnesse, Let him that is cleere herein, cast the first stone Iob • . • . at the application of this point. For albeit I knowe, some haue some better care then the multitude, yet I am sure, that the fiue wiser virgins, slumbred and slept while the bridgroome taried long, as well as the fiue foolish Mat • .2 • .: and therefore we shall not neede to shift off this doctrine from our selues to others, and to say, This is good for such or such, but we may say euery one to his owne soule, It is euen I to whom this belongeth. Wherefore seeing this is a matter which concernes all, I pray you let it be entertained by all: Let vs rouze vp our selues, let vs not crie with the sluggard, yet a little sleepe, a little slumber Prou. 6.10., but let vs make hastPsal. 119.6 • . with Dauid, and let vs bind our selues by a holy vow to cast away this hardned, brutish, presuming carelesnesse, as it were a menstruous cloth, and to say vnto it, Get thee hence Isa. 30 32.: Otherwise vnlesse we doe euen striue against this bewitching euill out of hand, we shall euen cleane be hardened with the deceitfulnesse of sinne Heb.3.13., we shall freeze vpon our dregs Zoph • .1 • ., and mooue the Lord to giue vs ouer with that fearefull doome, He that is filthie,
let him be filthie Re • . 22.11.. And surely if God might please so to blesse my speech, as that you might be mooued by it to thinke seriously with your owne soules, how true it is in this, which Abner said to Ioab when the people fought one against another, namely, that it will be bitternesse in the latter ende
〈…〉 ., you would then say to me as Dauid did to Abigaile, Blessed be thy Counsell
〈…〉 .. And so hoping that this first obseruation shall not vtterly fall to the ground without fruit, I come to the second, touching the contrary good which is perswaded.

And this (indeede) is still the remarkeable method of the Scripture, first to perswade a desisting from Euill, and then to stirre vp to the practise of good. Cease to doe Euill, learne to doe well Isa. • .16.17.. Abhorre that which is Euill, cleaue to that which is good. Rom. 12.9. To break off an euill course, and so to stoppe, is but the one half of a Christians dutie: To leaue one bad fashion, and then to begin another, is but an exchange of sinne, and no repentance.

The 2. part with the doctrine thereof. What mourning & heauinesse i • meant.Now the good commended here vnto vs is set downe by two names, Mourning and Heauines. In handling hereof it shall be our first inquirie to know what Mourning and what Heauinesse it is, here ment. As I said of Ioy, so I must of Mourning, it must necessarily be distinguished, and that by the Apostles direction. There is a Worldly Mourning, and there is a Godly Mourning 2. Cor. 7.10. A •• ofold mourning. 1. W • rldly m •• r • ing.. The Worldly Mourning, is a griefe and passion of the heart for worldly things, or else for spirituall things in a worldly respect. Both the branches of this worldly sorrow are ordinarie and common. Euery naturall man hath these affections to be grieued for losses of goods, of honours, of friends, &c. with paines and anguishes of bodie: Many are affected with these things extraordinarily. Now although these Touches are not simply euill (for it is a wickednes to be without naturall affection 2. 〈◊〉 . 3.3.,) yet the aime of S. Iames is not vnto them: There is another Branch of this Worldly Sorrow, the matter whereof is spirituall, but
the respects, carnall. Ahab was humbled1. King. 21.27. Esau weptGen. 27.38. Iudas was deepely touchedMatth. 27.3.. Here was Heauines, yea and the causes thereof were spirituall. Ahab for his oppression, Iudas for his trechery, Esau for the losse of the blessing: but the respects were not sutable. It was for the danger of Euil, and not for the Euill of Euill. Thus a man may be grieued, and yet neue • be saued. This kind of sorrow may be as a needle to p icke and to pierce the heart, and to make way for that true griefe, but it is not properly that which is ment in this place. For this sorrow in it selfe, and in it owne nature, if there be no more in it then I haue said, causeth death 2. Cor. 7.10.. Now the other Mourning is a Godly Mourning, that is, a Mourning for sinne because it is sinne, a breach of Gods will,2. Godly mourning. and an offence to his Maiestie. This is that very • hing which S. Iames perswades, and it is the Mother of true repentance, euen of that Repentance which (as S. Paul speaketh) is not to be repented of. And of this I will endeauour to speake as effectually as I can.

The ground of it is (as I haue said) the dishonour of God by sinne. Now sinne, that it may wound the more deepely, is to be considered of vs three waies.The matter of the mour ing here perswaded. 1. As it is in our selues. 2. As it is in others. 3. As it discouereth it selfe in the Miseries which it brings vpon the Times. Of these three Respects I will treat seuerally.

1. Our owne sinnes.1. That our owne sinnes must be mourned for, I suppose we will not denie. Repentance is of absolute necessitie to saluation, (for Except ye repent, ye shall perish, saith our SauiourLuk. 13.3.;) and there can be no repentance without griefe: For, (as we haue heard out of Paul) it is Godly sorow which causeth repentance to saluation. Besides, the Scripture hath registred euen a whole catalogue of Mourners in this kind. Looke into i • , you shall there see Dauid fainting Psal. 6.6., Hezekiah chattering like a crane Isa 38.14, Iob abhorring himselfe in dust and ashes Iob. 32. • ., Manasseh humbling himselfe greatly 2. Chro. 33.12., Ezra vpon his knees in heauines Ezra. 9.5., Daniel
sorowfully confessing his sinne, and seeking the Lord by prayer with fasting Da • . 9.3 20., Ephraim (the whole bodie of a state) smiting vpon the thigh Iere. 31.19., Peter weeping bitterly Math. 26.75., the father of the possessed child bewayling his vnbeleefe Mark. 9.24., Marie Magdalene washing Christs feete with teares Luk. 7.38. Paul crying out, O wretched man that I am Rom 7 24.! Who would not wish to be one in this companie. If they mourned, and went to heauen through the vale of Teares, what are we that we should expect a calmer passage? And know we this for a certentie, that the comforts of the Gospel which are treasured vp in Christ, appertaine onely to such: not to them which are at ease in Zion Am. 6.7., but to them which mourn in Zion Isa. 61.3. The spirit of heauines goeth before the garment of gladnes; and there is no Reaping in Ioy, without sowing in teares Psal. 126.5..

2. The sinne of others.The next consideration of sinne is, as it is in others: For euen the sinne of others must be a cause of sorrow to a Christian. Samuel mourned for Saul 1. Sam. 15.35., Dauids eies gushed out with riuers of waters, because men kept not the law Psal. 119.136.. Ezra rent his clothes, and plukt off the haire of his head and beard, when he heard of the peoples sinne, in mixing the holy seede with the people of the land Ezech. 9.2 3.; The soule of Ieremy wept in secret for the pride of the timesIer. 13.17.; Lot vexed his righteous soule in seeing and hearing the vnlawfull deeds of the Sodomites 2. Pet. 2.8.: Pauls spirit was stirred to see the City of Athens subiect to Idolatrie A • t. 17 16.: Christ mourned for the hardnes of mens hearts Mark 3 5., and wept for the securitie of IerusalemLuk. 19.41.: Who can perswade himselfe to cary the like Christian heart, who doth not bring forth the like sorrowing fruite? Two reasons there are why the the sinnes of others should affect our soules. 1. Pietie to God. 2. Pitie to them. First, Pietie to God enforceth it. For what dutifull respect can he carrie to God, who can heare and see God to be dishonoured without any touch? It grieues a friend to heare the disgrace of his friend. The godly are called the Friends of God Iam 2.23. Ioh. 15.15. A poore
friendship it is, if the heart be not effected with a wrong done to his Maiestie. Secondly, Pitie to others requireth it. For whose bowels that hath in him any dramme of goodnes, would not yearne within him, whose heart would not melt, to see whole swarmes, and millions of people which will needes be damned? surely there can be no religion, where there wants this compassion. I haue read of Marcellus a Romane, that when as after a long siege, he entred by composition into that rich city of Syracusa, the teares trickled downe h • s cheekes, to see so famous a city & such a multitude of Inhabitants brought into captiuitie. See, what affections haue dwelt euen in the Heathen, begetting sorrow for the miseries euen of their enemies. A shame for a Christian to behold the daily ruine of a world of soules, number-les troupes to be led as captiues by the prince of darknesse, and not to bemone it.

3. The Calamities of the Times.The third consideration of sinne is, as it discouereth it selfe in the miseries, which by the iustice of God it brings vpon the Times: which thing also must be taken to heart. Thus was Dauid mooued, when he saw multitudes swept away with the Pestilence2. Sam. 24 17.. Ieremie wished his head full of water, and his eyes a fountaine of teares, that he might weepe day and night for the slaine of the people Ier 9 1. and let his book of Lamentations be a testimonie of his griefe for common Miseries. So there was a generall sorrow, when God tooke away that peere-les king Iosiah; Ieremiah lamented, singing men and singing women mourned 2. Chr. 35 25.. Nehemiah sate and wept and mourned certaine dates, when he heard of the great affliction and reproch of his countrymen, the remainder of the great captiuitieNehe. 1.3 4.. Ester and her maides fasted, because of Hamans conspiracieEst. 4.16.. It argueth a desperate case when men are not humbled by Afflictions: Thou hast smitten them, but they haue not sorowed: thou hast consumed them, but they haue refused to receiue corre • tion, saide the Prophet
of the forlorne IewesIer. 5 3.. Thence cōmeth that extraordinatie note set vpon Ahaz, not found elswhere: In the time of his tribulation did he yet trespasse more against the Lord: this is king Ahaz 2. Chr. 28.23. This is the man who was not brought to any humiliation, no not by Affliction. And although a man haue no cause of deiection, in regard of any personall grieuance, yet the miseries of others are a sufficient motiue. And therefore it is noted as a sauage and bruitish part, that when the citie of Shushan, was in perplexitie, the King and Haman sate drinking in the palace
• st. 3.15. and woe is threatened against them which cherished themselues, but were not sory for the Affliction of Ioseph Amo 6.6. For that cause, Nehemiah, though he himselfe were well enough, beeing the Kings butler, and in speciall grace with him, yet he professed that he could not but be sad, so long as he heard of the hard estate of his countrymenNehe. 1.11.2.3. and though Moses liued at ease in Pharaohs court, yet still his mind was vpon the burdens of the Israelites, and had no rest in himselfe vntill he went to visit his brethren Act. 7.23.: and Vriah would not afford himselfe the ordinarie comfort of his Bed, so long as the Arke of God was in hazard2. Sam. 11.11. Thus the fruits of sinne, whether they be personall, or such as lie vpon others, or such as (because of the common concernement of a state) we are interessed in with others, must be taken notice of to further that Holy Heauinesse, which is commended to vs in this place. Thus I haue opened the doctrine, touching that Mourning and Heauinesse for sinne, into which S. Iames would haue vs to turne all our accustomed securitie. I come now to the vse and application hereof to our selues.

In the making of which vse & application I will follow this order.The Vse. 1. I will make it manifest that we haue these causes of Mourning which haue beene handled hitherte. 2. I will lay open the generall defect of this dutie, notwithstanding the vrgency of these causes. 3. I will labour
the perswading of that, to doe which we haue so great cause, and yet in the doing whereof we haue beene so exceeding negligent. These be (as it were) the lines, vnto each of which I must endeuour to giue his proper filling.

We haue • he three C •• ses of Hea ••• e ••• .First, I must make it good that we haue this treble cause of heauines. 1. Our owne sinnes: 2. The sinnes of the Times. 3. The euidences of Gods displeasure against sinne. Touching our owne sinnes, that in the multitude and grieuousnes of them, we haue much matter of Heauines, no man (I suppose) will denie. First for multitude, he that shall heare Dauids acknowledgement, that his sinnes are moe in number then the haires of his head Psal. 40 1 • ., and Iobs confession, that he cannot answer God one of a thousand Iob. 9. •
, how can he thinke his sinnes are few? And if there be any here (as this secure age brings forth many such) who supposeth the tale of his sinnes to be but small, let him doe but this: Let him in the end of some one day, examine his course vpon his bed Psal. 4 4. and proceed with himselfe from point to point, from his waking in the morping to that houre, calling all (as neere as he possibly can) his thoughts, speaches, actions to a • eckning: and then, when he hath found by a suruey made, the idle, vnprofitable, god-les thoughts, which haue beene as thicke within him, as motes in the aire, the vaine, vitious, blasphemous, grace-les speeches which haue fallen from his mouth, the euills which he hath done, the good duties, to God, to himselfe, to others, which he hath left vndone, or (at lest) not so done as he should: when (I say) he hath found out all these, and hath (as his dutie is) added this withall, that besides, there are many secret faultes Psal. • 9.1 • . which he cannot see; then let him (like the workman, who by the sight of Hercules his foote, gathered the proportion of his whole bodie) thinke, put case he hath liued thirtie, fourty, or more yeares, what infinite millions of sinnes, he must needs be guilty of, sith the
particulars of one day doe amount to so great a summe. This would make euen the stoutest to hang downe his head like a bulrush, and to be (as it were) confounded in himselfe if this were duly thought vpon. It is said of Cesar, that when he heard that a certain Knight of Rome, being dead, and whose goods were set to sale, was in debt some thousand of poundes, be wished that the knights bolster might be bought for his vse, thinking, that sure it had some extraordinarie vertue in it, vpon which a man could sleeepe who was so much in debt: And surely, if we had but a glimpse of the particular Debtes

And (indeede,) the not looking into the hinder ende of the wallet, is the cause of all our presuming. We are like swaggerers at a tauerne, who (in their humour) call in for as much as the house can afford, but when the shot commeth, then they storme, and are readie to sweare, it cannot be so much: so we run on still vpon the lash, and neuer looke on the score, little doe we thinke it to be so great as indeede it is. He amongst vs, who is accustomed to swearing, though it be but now and then, yet if it were possible for him, to see but how many times he had sworne in the compasse of one yeare, (besides his other sins,) I verely think, that if he were not vtterly giuen ouer, it would make his belly to tremble
〈◊〉 2.16., to consider it. Howsoeuer, this let vs be sure of, they are all downe in Gods Register
• al. 56.8., and Iob saith, that God sealeth vp iniquities as in a bag
•• b. 14.1 • ., as rich men do their mony, laying it vp vntill the Audit. Now for the grieuousnes of our sins (which is another branch) I will note but one circumstance of many to set it out; and that is, the Riches of the meanes which we haue long enioyed, for better fruit. Suppose we, that we euen now did heare the Lord calling
to vs as he did of old to the Iewes, Come let vs reason togither Isa. 1.14., thinke earnestly what excuse we can make. Hath not the Lord beene patient towards vs? hath he not waited that he might haue mercie vpon vs Isa • 0. •• .; hath he not sent vnto vs early and late, Cast away your transgressions, why will ye dieE • ock. 1 • . ••
? Hath not the light of holy direction long stood vpon a candlestick in the midst of vs? haue we not still heard that voice, This is the way walke in it Isa. 30 11. ? Now this is a sure thing: by how much the more we know, or may know, by so much the greater is our sinne. If I had not come and spoken vnto them, they had had no sinne, but now haue they no cloke for their sinne Ioh. 15. •• .; Thus the enlargemēt of Gods mercie in blessing vs with the means of holines, is the greatest improuemont of our sinne: And so (I hope) I haue cleered this, that we haue the first cause of Heauines, our own sinnes: touching which it is hard to say, which is the greater, the multitude of them, or their qualitie.

The next cause of sorrowe, which must be manifested to be amongst vs, is the sinne of the Times. It was truely said that the Deuill hath great wra • h, knowing that he hath but a short time Reu. 12 1 • .. As his time is abridged, so is his malice enlarged; and thence it is, that this old Age of the world, is so fruitfull in most monstrous impieties. All the euills of the precedent ages, are flowne together into this, as into a common sewer. The filthinesse of the people hath filled the land from corner to corner Ez • 29.11. Men were wont heretofore, amid their other euills, yet to haue so much honesty, as to seeke to shrowd their sinnes vnder a mantle of secrecy. But now they declare them as Sodom Isa. 3.9., Atheisme, Blasphemie, Drunkennesse, Whoredome, Oppression, Contempt of religion, men neuer blush to be commonly noted for such kinds of euills. Indeede nothing (among the multitude) is in more disgrace then this, to be a conscionable and carefull Christian. Me thinkes, considering the full measure of Iniquitie, I
should heare the Lord cry to his Angel, Thrust in thy sicle and reape, for the time is come to reape, the Haruest of the Earth is ripe Re • . 14.15.. Woe be to vs if we crie not with David, It is time for thee Lord to work, for they haue destroyed thy law Psal 119.126. So much briefly for that, which if my Tongue were as the pen of a swift writer Psa • 5.1., I were not able to set downe at full, and which if we might reforme with the sacrifice of our best blood; we might thinke it well bestowed. Thus we see the second cause of heauinesse is not wanting. We can scarcely put our heads out at doors, or heare one speake, but we shall haue cause to remember it.

The third thing deseruing sorrowe, to be handled, are the Euidences (in the times) of Gods displeasure against sinne. The prophet Amos saith, that there is no euill (meaning, no euill of punishment) but the Lord hath done it A • o 3 6., and Ieremie saith, that euery such Euill is an infliction for sinne; Man suffereth for his sinne I • am 3 39.: which t • o places doe euince thus much, that if there haue been amongst vs any common punishments, surely they haue come from the Lord, and that for sinne. Now what common Punishments the Lord hath laied vpon our Times, he must needes be blind which seeth not. A raging, and (as I may rearme it) a man-eating pestilence in the chiefe parts of the kingdome (though we hitherto in these West parts, haue beene euen miraculously spared: but let vs not presume, if we haue beene idle lookers on, vpon the visitations of others, the rod will fal the heauier when it comes) vnseasonable seasons, vnheard of inundations, fearefull fires, the foules of heauen, and the fishes of the sea destroyed
•• ph. 1.3.. These things we heare, these things we discourse of at our Tables, and in our meetings as newes, and as the occurences of the Times, but we let them die with the report, and neuer put them vpon our hearts. What thinke we of the horrible oppression which raigneth, one man labouring to cate and deuoure another Gal. 5.13.,
the encreasing of Papists, who (like the Cananites to the Israelites) are as a whippe on our sides, or as Thornes in our Eyes Ios • . 23.13., the grosse fatnesse which is growne vpon most hearts, in that (like the Iewes in Christs time) men doe not esteeme nor knowe the things which appertaine vnto their peace Luk. 19.42. ? What thinke we (I say) of these things? doe they not giue vs cause to say as Moses did to Aaron, when God sent a suddaine pestilence among the people, There is wrath gone out from the Lord, the plague is begun Num 16.46. yes verely. Nay we may well exspect, the accomplishment of that which was said of olde, namely, that if we be not reformed by these things, the Lord will smite vs yet seuen times more for our sianes Leu. 16.24.. Truth is, God hath beene and is, very gracious to our dayes (for so is his manner, oft times to call back his anger, and not to stirre vp all his wrath Psal. 78 38.,) he hath set • eace in our borders Psal. 14 • .14., vnder the gouernment of a Christian King, he hath not remooued our Candlesticke, as he iustly might, because of the decay of our first loue Reu. 2.4 5., yet euen this is also to be counted a iudgement, that the eyes of the most are so holden, that they doe not see Gods mercie, nor knowe how to turne these fauours to a spirituall vse, and full is euery place of such Fooles, (as Salonton speakes of) who haue a price in their hands, but haue none heart to get wisdome Pron. 17.16. And this may serue to let vs • ee what Euidences we haue of the Lords displeasure against sinne, and withall, to make good the first point, that we haue abundant matter of Heauinesse.

We haue • ot sorrowed • s we should.Now let me shew our neglect, & what slender sorrow these things haue brought forth amongst vs; I will proceed distinctly and in order: and first what little mourning there is for personall sinnes: The seate of sorrow is the heart, (Rent your hearts, saith IoelIoel. 2.13.), and that only Knoweth the bitternes of the soule. f Prou. 14.10. It is vnpossible that I should be priuie to mens secret bewaylings, neither wil I iudge any, by the smoothnes of his looke, or the drines
of his cheeks; for euery cloud doth not drop down raine, neither is euery mist of sorrow dissolued into teares: Yet there is one thing by which it may be shrewdly suspected that (to speak of the generalitie) men are in very litle heauinesse for their sinnes, and that is, the little reformation which appeares. The mourning heart cannot but be displeased in it selfe, for the Euills which it hath ommitted Ezeck. 6.9. This displeasure will turne the delight in sinne, into a hatred of sinne. This hatred will bring forth that which Paul calleth Care 2. Cor. 7 11., that is, a pensiue and busie studie how to amend: And it cannot be but God would so blesse these motions, (beeing indeed the workings of his owne spirit) as that sinne, beeing quailed in the roote, shall also wither in the leafe, and the loue of holines being planted in the heart, shall shoote out some fruite in the life. I know it is possible, for a deare child of God, bitterly to bewaile some speciall corruption, confidently to vow against it, earnestly to beg deliuerance from it, to striue to subdue it with the vtmost might, & yet again & again to be ensnared with it: But, that Wickednes should be sweet in a mans mouth Iob. 20.12., that he should obey it in the lusts thereof Rom. 6.12., that he should take thought for it to fulfill it Rom. 13.14., that he should hate to be reformed Psal. 50.17., and yet be said, to mourne and be heauy for his sinne, sure I am it is vnpossible. He mourneth not for drunkennes, who riseth early to follow it Isa. 5.11.: He mourneth not for couetousnes, who is plotting and imagining matters of oppression and vniust getting vpon his bed Micah. 2.1.. He mourneth not for swearing, who saith, With my tongue I will preuaile, what hath any bodie to doe, who is Lord ouer me Psal. 12 4. ? and so in other specialties: so that this then is a true conclusion: There is but little amendment of sinne, therefore sure there is but little sorrowe for sinne.

And that is touching our beeing affected with the tokens which we see of Gods wrath against sinne. And surely the very face of things (as they nowe stand) is sufficient to bewray the iron deadnesse of mens hearts in this particular. All things doe euen sauour of an vniuersall securitie. Many blowes are giuen, but the people turne not vnto him that smiteth Isa. 9.13.. The wofull occurrences of the Times, haue the same working with men which a great stone hath when it falleth into the Waters. Falling in, it maketh a great noise, and stirreth the Water verie much, and one waue begetteth another for a good pretie space, at last the motion groweth weaker and weaker, and the Water returneth againe vnto his former smoothnes. So in this: We heare of diuers searefull accidents: at the first comming of the newes, we are much mooued, and it runneth from man to man, with much swiftnes; but on a suddaine, when this first addresse is past, the matter dieth away, we are as we were, and the thing it selfe leaues no impression; and by this meanes is that veresied, which was complained of old, The Lord calleth vnto weeping & mourning, and behold Ioy and gladnes, slaying oxen & killing sheepe, eating flesh and drinking wine, Isa 22 12.13. &c. No humiliation followeth vpon Gods iudgements. But whereas euery Iudgement of God should be as a warning peale to repentance, we be like the smiths dog, who, the harder the anuile is beaten on, lyeth by and sleepes the sounder, so a deeper kind of drowsinesse hath ouertaken vs.

Now then that these two points are cleared, the one touching the causes of Heauinesse which we haue, the other touching our scantnesse in framing our selues to that measure of holy sorrowe which becommeth vs, surely, if we suppose any waight to be in this which is commended
to vs by S. Iames, I doubt not but I shall easily perswade you in the generall drift of my whole sermon, namely to turne your Laughter into Mourning, and your Ioy into heauinesse. For the better furtherance whereof let me commend vnto your best consideration these particulars.

To draw then to a conclusion. You see a dutie commended to vs, by the mouth and ministerie of S. Iames, to turne our Careles Laughter into a holy Mourning, & our presuming Ioy into a godly Heavines. It is not without cause that we are perswaded to this exchange. Looke we into our selues, our own sinns muster together before our eies in no small troupes, inough to wound the dullest heart. Cast we our face to others, we see the world lying in wickednes 1. Ioh 5. •• ., and Hell euen enlarging it selfe Isa. 5 12., to receiue it: Examine we the times, many things tell vs plainely, that surely God is not well pleased. Consider we againe our owne course we must needs yee • d, that we haue bin two secure, and that these things haue not so affected vs as they should: Thinke we further of the benefite and worth of that which we are persward • d to, we shall find it attended vpon with a traine of blessings. How shall we then denie our obedience to this holy aduise; I pray you then, Let my counsell be acceptable vnto you Dan 4.2.. You are here, many Marchants, and much of your trading stands
vpon exchangeA particular application to the place where 〈…〉 .. Well is he in his owne opinion who can put away some ill-conditioned ware for a more current cōmodity. Behold here the best exchāge which you euer made, Let your Laughter be turned into Mourning, and your Ioy into Heauines. Sure I am, a commodity it is, for which (which all desire) you shall receiue a very quicke and plentifull returne. Quick it will be, For yet a very little while, and he that shall come will come and he will not tary H •• 1 • 3 • .: and it will be plentifull, for they which now goe weeping, shall returnne with ioy, nay which is more, they shall bring their sheaues I ••
